title: Broadcom’s VMware License Controversy: Cease-and-Desist Letters Sent to Perpetual Users
summary:
Broadcom has been sending cease-and-desist letters to owners of VMware perpetual licenses with expired support contracts, Ars Technica has confirmed.

Following its November 2023 acquisition of VMware, Broadcom ended VMware perpetual license sales. Users with perpetual licenses can still use the software they bought, but they are unable to renew support services unless they had a pre-existing contract enabling them to do so. The controversial move aims to push VMware users to buy subscriptions to VMware products bundled such that associated costs have increased by 300 percent or, in some cases, more.

Some customers have opted to continue using VMware unsupported, often as they research alternatives, such as VMware rivals or devirtualization.

full_text_content:
Broadcom has been sending cease-and-desist letters to owners of VMware perpetual licenses with expired support contracts, Ars Technica has confirmed.
Following its November 2023 acquisition of VMware, Broadcom ended VMware perpetual license sales. Users with perpetual licenses can still use the software they bought, but they are unable to renew support services unless they had a pre-existing contract enabling them to do so. The controversial move aims to push VMware users to buy subscriptions to VMware products bundled such that associated costs have increased by 300 percent or, in some cases, more.
Some customers have opted to continue using VMware unsupported, often as they research alternatives, such as VMware rivals or devirtualization.
Over the past weeks, some users running VMware unsupported have reported receiving cease-and-desist letters from Broadcom informing them that their contract with VMware and, thus, their right to receive support services, has expired. The letter [PDF], reviewed by Ars Technica and signed by Broadcom managing director Michael Brown, tells users that they are to stop using any maintenance releases/updates, minor releases, major releases/upgrades extensions, enhancements, patches, bug fixes, or security patches, save for zero-day security patches, issued since their support contract ended.
The letter tells users that the implementation of any such updates “past the Expiration Date must be immediately removed/deinstalled," adding:
Any such use of Support past the Expiration Date constitutes a material breach of the Agreement with VMware and an infringement of VMware’s intellectual property rights, potentially resulting in claims for enhanced damages and attorneys’ fees.
Some customers of Members IT Group, a managed services provider (MSP) in Canada, have received this letter, despite not receiving VMware updates since their support contracts expired, CTO Dean Colpitts told Ars. One customer, he said, received a letter six days after their support contract expired.
Similarly, users online have reported receiving cease-and-desist letters even though they haven't issued updates since losing VMware support. One user on Spiceworks’ community forum reported receiving such a letter even though they migrated off of VMware and to Proxmox.

seo_agent_results.generated_article_body_md:
## Broadcom’s VMware License Controversy: Cease-and-Desist Letters Sent to Perpetual Users Broadcom has intensified the **VMware license controversy** by issuing cease-and-desist letters to users holding VMware perpetual licenses with expired support contracts. Following its acquisition of VMware in November 2023, Broadcom discontinued perpetual license sales, forcing users to either transition to costly subscription bundles—reportedly up to 300% more expensive—or operate without support. Now, unsupported users are receiving legal warnings demanding they stop using updates released after their contracts expired, even if they never installed them. ### Unpacking Broadcom’s Aggressive Enforcement Broadcom’s cease-and-desist letters, signed by managing director Michael Brown, explicitly prohibit the use of any VMware updates—including patches, bug fixes, or security enhancements—beyond the expiration date of a user’s support contract. The letters frame continued use as a "material breach" and an infringement of VMware’s intellectual property, threatening legal action for damages and attorneys’ fees. Reports indicate that some recipients, such as clients of Canadian MSP Members IT Group, received these warnings just days after their contracts lapsed, despite not having installed updates. Even users who migrated to alternatives like Proxmox have been targeted, raising questions about Broadcom’s enforcement strategy. #### The Fallout for VMware Customers The move has left many VMware users scrambling for alternatives, with some opting for competitors like Nutanix or considering **devirtualization**—a costly and complex process. Critics argue that Broadcom’s tactics prioritize short-term revenue over customer retention, potentially alienating long-term VMware adopters. #### Pros & Cons
Pros
- Encourages adoption of modern subscription models, ensuring continuous revenue for Broadcom. - May streamline VMware’s product offerings by phasing out legacy licensing.
Cons
- Alienates loyal VMware customers with aggressive legal tactics. - Forces businesses into expensive subscriptions or risky unsupported usage.
#### Frequently Asked Questions
Can I still use VMware without a support contract?

Yes, but Broadcom’s cease-and-desist letters prohibit using any updates released after your contract expired, including critical security patches.

What are the alternatives to VMware?

Options include Proxmox, Nutanix, Microsoft Hyper-V, or devirtualizing workloads—though each comes with migration challenges.
